clinical_study.brief_title: Risk Stratification of Multicenter Patients With Heart Failure
clinical_study.official_title: Risk Stratification of Multicenter Patients With Heart Failure: Clinic, Labortary Test and Cardiovascular Magnetic Resonance Imaging

brief_summary.textblock: Heart failure (HF) is the final stage of the heart disease. The prevalence of heart failure continues to rise, but the diagnosis and treatment is not satisfactory. At present, there is no relatively ideal model to predict the adverse cardiovascular events in patients with heart failure and carry out effective clinical intervention. Cardiac magnetic resonance can directly reflect the cardiac structure, function and myocardial characteristics of patients with heart failure. This study aimed to establish the relationship between cells, molecules and clinic with the help of image bridge, and establish the risk model of heart failure based on demographic data, symptoms, laboratory tests and emerging magnetic resonance imaging technologies (T1 mapping / ECV, feature tracking, CEST).

detailed_description.textblock:
Heart failure (HF) is the final stage of the heart disease which refers to the disorder of systolic and (or) diastolic function of the heart. At present, there are about 50 models to predict the risk of death in patients with heart failure. Most models use demographic, complications, and laboratory tests to risk HF patients. The main risk factors included age, renal function, blood pressure, sodium level, ejection fraction, gender, BNP level, NYHA cardiac function classification, diabetes mellitus and body mass index. However, there is no relatively ideal model to predict the adverse cardiovascular events in patients with heart failure and carry out effective clinical intervention. One of the main factors is that the risk factors of almost all existing heart failure models are mostly based on demographic data, symptoms, laboratory tests, etc. These indicators are not specific, insensitive and do not directly reflect the heart status of patients with heart failure. There is a lack of relevant parameters to reflect the mechanism and its secondary pathophysiological changes of heart failure.
Cardiovascular magnetic resonance has become an increasingly important noninvasive imaging tool for the diagnosis, treatment and prognosis of cardiovascular diseases, Emerging techniques such as T1 / 2 mapping, extracellular volume, perfusion imaging, , BOLD fMRI and chemical exchange saturation transfer (CEST) imaging have emerged rapidly. It is possible to interpret the pathogenesis and related pathophysiological changes of heart failure and establish a new risk model of death and adverse cardiovascular events.
Based on the emerging magnetic resonance imaging technologies (T1 mapping / ECV, feature tracking, CEST and other technologies), this study aims to establish the relationship between cells, molecular and clinic with the help of imaging. Through one-stop scanning, we can not only obtain the relevant information of diagnosis, but also establish the risk model of death of heart failure based on cardiac magnetic resonance. Through the one-stop magnetic resonance examination, establishing a comprehensive risk model of cardiac death of heart failure, and take targeted intervention measures for people with different risks, so as to achieve early intervention, early treatment, improve the prognosis of patients, and provide guidance for clinicians.

study_pop.textblock: This study is a prospective, multicenter study with HF patients, diagnosed based on the World Health Organization/International Society and Federation of Cardiology definition of Heart failure.The inclusion criteria include left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF)<50%. LV end-diastolic volume >2SD from normal according to normograms corrected by body surface area (BSA) and age. We exclude patients with severe arrhythmia; Contraindications to CMR; Refuse to participate in the study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF<50%)
2. LV end-diastolic volume >2SD from normal according to normograms corrected by body surface area (BSA) and age.
Exclusion Criteria:
- 1)Severe arrhythmia; 2)Contraindications to CMR 3)Refuse to participate in the study
